lg.l: [blank] Matthiessen, Renaissance (see earlier note). that he cld hear every day in the street or workshop.

[blank] 38 E’s continual joy in the homeliest speech . . . or in the understatements
[blank] of the farmers who referred to mountain peaks . . . as ‘them ere rises’
[blank]
[blank] 38 Professor Francis Bowen (in the review of Nature): ‘Emerson is in
[blank] trans. of Tocqueville
[blank] love with the old Saxon idiom, yet there is a spice of affectation
[blank] in his mode of using it. He is sometimes coarse & blunt, that he
[blank] may avoid the imputation of sickly refinement, . . . e.g. Whilst we
[blank] use this grand cipher to expedite the affairs of our pot & kettle.
[blank]
[blank] 39 Manifest Destiny, Democracy, Freedom, fine names for an
[blank] ugly thing. They call it otto of rose and lavender,—I call it bilge-
[blank] water.’
[blank] vocab. of new discoveries, Humboldt’s ‘magnetic storms,’
[blank] and ‘veins inosculate,’ or in that electric phrase, ‘arrested
[blank] development,’ in Chambers’s Vestiges of Creation.
[blank]
[blank] 40 Em. Literature ‘the finest tool of all’ in being ‘nearest to the mind.’
[blank]
[blank] 5 ‘The Light of the Body is the Eye’
[blank] He held it the poet’s function to cast enchantment over just
[blank] such seemingly humble & trivial objects. (as the sea-shell)
[blank] 45 Being’s tide
[blank] Swells hitherward, & myriads of forms
[blank] Live robed w. beauty, painted by the sun;
[blank] Their dust, pervaded by the nerves of God,
[blank] Throbs w an overmastering energy
[blank] Knowing and doing.
[blank] . . . ebbs the tide, they lie
[blank] White hollow shells upon the desert shore.
[blank]
[blank] 45 When I got home I could find nothing that I gathered—
[blank] nothing but some dry, ugly mussel & snail shells. Thence I learned
[blank] that composition was more important than the beauty of individual forms

[blank] Matthiessen, Renaissance (see earlier note). to effect. On the shore they lay wet & social by the sea & under
[blank] the sky.’
[blank] cf. ‘Each & All’ . . . : ‘the perfect whole.’
[blank] 46 The irregularity with which he tried to
[blank] mount to paradise
[blank] By the stairway of surprise,”
[blank] was not Merlin’s, but more nearly an echo of what Herbert
[blank] and Donne had suggested to him. But lacking their
[blank] dramatic concentration, his conceits could often run to seed,
[blank] as in the dizzy waywardness of ‘The Humble Bee.’
[blank]
[blank] 47 . . . wrote to Lydia Jackson shortly before their marriage in 1835:
[blank] I am born a poet,—of a low class without doubt, yet a poet.
[blank] . . . My singing, be sure, is very husky, & is for the most part
[blank] in prose. Still I am a poet in the sense of a perceiver
[blank] & dear lover of the harmonies that are in the soul
[blank] & in matter, & specially of the correspondences bet. these &
[blank] those.’
[blank] 48 What else is it to be a poet? . . . What but a sensibility so keen
[blank] that the scent of an elder-blow, or the timberyard & corporation
[blank] poet works of a nest of pismires is event enough for him,—all
[blank] emblems and personal appeals to him.
[blank]
[blank] 49 The Rhodora cf To a Waterfowl (Bryant)
[blank]
[blank] 49 chapter in Nature that deals w ‘bBeauty’ Beauty
[blank] the simple perception of natural forms is a delight.
[blank]
[blank] 49 ‘For other things, I make poetry of them, but the moral
[blank] sentiment makes poetry of me.’ Wanted the sentiment
[blank] ‘to blend with & pervade the whole. Beauty could
[blank] express it, without apology; yet even in saying that,
[blank] he betrays his background. A lingering trace of doubt

[blank] Matthiessen, Renaissance (see earlier note). causes him to make an excuse in the very act of saying
[blank] that one is not needed.
[blank] proportion
[blank] 50 economy
[blank] avoidance of surface embellishments
[blank]
[blank] 50 his almost exclusive absorption with seeing.
[blank] . . . said he had not a musical car, he had ‘musical eyes.’
[blank] . . . there is no object that intense light will not make beautiful.
[blank] 51 the poet is the man ‘whose eye can integrate all the parts.’
[blank]
[blank] 52 Emerson: ‘the sensual man conforms thoughts to things; the poet
[blank] conforms things to his thoughts.’ could be interpreted
[blank] variously, but the drift of E’s meaning is shown by
[blank] his acceptance of Bacon’s formula for poetry—
[blank] “Poetry, not finding the actual world xactly conformed
[blank] to its idea of good and fair, seeks to accommodate the
[blank] shows of things to the desires of the mind, & to create an
[blank] ideal world better than the world of xperience.’ cf. the view
[blank] that the greatest art comes fr. immersion in the complexities of experience
[blank] oesie
[blank] Bacon: (P.) was ever thought to have some participation of divineness
[blank] bec. it doth raise & erect the mind, by submitting the shows
[blank] of things to the desires of the mind; whereas reason doth
[blank] buckle & bow the mind into the nature of things.’
[blank] cf. Bacon’s: “For as for Poesy, it is rather a pleasure or
[blank] play of Imagination, than a work or duty thereof”; &
[blank] “History is the best of all the liberal arts—I had
[blank] almost said of only use; for poets I can commend none,
[blank] being resolved to be ever a stranger to them.”
[blank]
[blank] 53 his four-beat couplet seems to be pounding on monotonously
[blank] . . . not fused with the phrases that are brought to fit it.
[blank] Thoreau to Emerson: “The tune is altogether unworthy of the
[blank] thoughts. You slope too quickly to the rhyme . . . It sounds
[blank] like parody . . . Yet I love your poetry when you get fairly round the
[blank] end of the line, & are not thrown back upon the rocks.”
[blank]
